item.title: Skate Breaks No Paywall Promise for New Map: "Sometimes Plans Change"
item.content:encoded:
EA has reneged on one of its promises for last year's Skate reboot, namely that the game will feature "no map areas locked behind paywalls".

In a news post outlining what's coming to Skate in the future, EA says that the game's third season will introduce the new Isle of Grom map, which has been expanded and filled with new areas to explore.

Initially, only Skate Pass Premium holders will be able to explore the Isle of Grom, but after the first month, the map will be opened up to everyone for a "very special multi-week event". That event is limited, though; afterwards, you'll have to pay in one form or another to access the Isle of Grom.

After the aforementioned "very special" event, you'll either need to hold the Skate Pass Premium or pay in-game Rip Chips to access the Isle of Grom, and the latter will only net you a 24-hour pass, so it's not permanent.

Technically speaking - and I mean real fine-print technical here - the new map isn't really locked behind a paywall per se, because you can theoretically access it without paying real money.

Still, though, I'd say this is a contravention of what EA promised all the way back in 2022 in spirit, if not absolutely in letter. It's not a great look to need to argue the finer detail rather than the broader picture.

Perhaps more insultingly, in response to a player asking why EA stepped away from the no-maps-behind-paywalls promise, the company rather dismissively says that "plans have to change" sometimes, and that "that's part of the deal when you're building in public".

In fact, one X user points out that just one week ago, Skate's website FAQ declared that "new areas of San Vansterdam (the game's world) will always be free and available to all players...if it's there, you can go there". Suffice it to say the FAQ no longer features that passage.

Of course, the obvious question to ask here is this: if EA can walk back this promise, what's to stop the company ditching the others in the above image too? How long before Skate features pay-to-win elements, paid loot boxes, or paid gameplay advantages?

For now, at the very least, if you want to access Skate's Isle of Grom map beyond May, you're going to have to pay for it in some form. Stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Pokemon Presents to Celebrate the Series' 30th Anniversary Next Week
item.content:encoded:
Well, it's official: there's going to be a Pokemon Presents showcase next week, and it'll mark the series' 30th anniversary with new information about what's on the horizon for Pokemon.

Of course, a Pokemon Presents has taken place on February 27th every year for the past few years, so it probably shouldn't come as too much of a surprise that that's the date for this year's presentation as well.

The showcase will air at 6am Pacific (that's 9am Eastern and 2pm GMT), and it'll give us a look at "the latest news and updates from the world of Pokemon" before what The Pokemon Company describes as "a year's worth of Pokemon fun" begins.

We already know one thing that's going to be featured during the show, namely the Switch release of Pokemon FireRed and LeafGreen, which was confirmed earlier today. The games will launch just after the showcase concludes.

What else we'll see during this Pokemon Presents is a mystery for now, although we can make some educated guesses; it's likely that mobile games Pokemon Cafe ReMix and Pokemon Masters EX will appear, as they usually do, and we'll probably hear from Pokemon Unite as well.

Outside of the realms of virtual certainty, I'd be very surprised indeed if this presentation doesn't contain at least a nod to the upcoming tenth Pokemon generation. Back in October, a massive Pokemon leak seemingly revealed details about gen ten, so the clock's ticking on an official reveal.

We may also see more DLC announced for last year's Pokemon Legends: Z-A. The game sold very well indeed, so a second DLC pack after December's Mega Dimension seems like a good idea.

Whatever gets announced, the next Pokemon Presents will be airing on February 27th at 6am PT/9am ET/2pm GMT. It'll be viewable on YouTube or Twitch.

item.title: NieR: Automata Sales Cross 10m as Followup Seemingly Teased
item.content:encoded:
Square Enix has revealed that NieR: Automata has crossed another major sales milestone, and if a new teaser is to be believed, more NieR could finally be on the way.

Per a message on the official NieR X account, NieR: Automata has officially sold over 10 million copies. That figure counts across both digital and physical sales, naturally, and it also includes all platforms on which the game is currently available.

The new sales figure means that NieR: Automata has racked up another million sales for itself since December 2024. Who said single-player games don't sell anymore? Perhaps this will convince the purse-string holders at the top that live-service isn't the only way.

There's reason to hope that more NieR could be coming, too. At the conclusion of a new video celebrating the 10 million achievement, a message simply reads "NieR: Automata to be continued...".

It's worth noting that the rest of the video is entirely in Japanese, so it's possible that this is a mistranslation, or that the message simply points to more NieR: Automata media in future. Perhaps a current-gen port could even be on the cards.

Still, NieR: Automata remains the last new mainline release in the NieR series at time of writing, so I don't think it's unreasonable to hope that Square Enix could be gearing up to give Yoko Taro another chance to hold the reins this year.

You can watch the aforementioned video, which celebrates NieR: Automata's achievements over the years, right here.

If you're unfamiliar with NieR: Automata, it's an action game that serves as a collaboration between iconoclastic designer Yoko Taro and action luminaries PlatinumGames.

The game revolves around 2B, an android who slowly begins to question her existence as a war with machines threatens to develop into something more complex than she initially believed.

You can check out NieR: Automata right now on PC, PlayStation 4, Xbox One, and Nintendo Switch, and it's playable on current-gen systems through backwards compatibility as well. You can read our original review of the game here.

item.title: Nioh 3 Sales Hit 1m, Breaking a Franchise Record
item.content:encoded:
Team Ninja and Koei Tecmo have revealed that their Soulslike action RPG Nioh 3 has crossed a major sales barrier, thus also breaking a franchise record in the process.

In a news post on the game's official website, Koei Tecmo announces that Nioh 3 sales have passed one million since the game launched at the start of the month, which makes this third installment the "fastest-selling entry in the series' history".

Not only that, but the Nioh series as a whole has now passed 10 million sales, which presumably means that the first two games in the franchise clocked up 9 million sales between them. That's not too shabby, and we can probably expect Nioh 3 to compete with its forebears on this front, at the very least.

In general, it seems that Nioh 3 is part of an upward trend for Koei Tecmo when it comes to initial sales; back in 2024, the studio also revealed that its Bakumatsu-era RPG Rise of the Ronin had surpassed the first two Nioh games in terms of launch sales.

If you're not familiar with Nioh 3, it is, believe it or not, the third game in the Nioh series, which blends Souls-esque combat and exploration with a focus on loot gathering and fast-paced combat.

In contrast to its predecessors, Nioh 3 allows you to travel between various eras in Japanese history, including the aforementioned Bakumatsu era, as well as the Edo, Sengoku, and Heian periods.

Much like in Team Ninja's other Soulslike RPG Wo Long: Fallen Dynasty, you'll meet and interact with historical figures from throughout these periods, including the likes of Hattori Hanzo, Minamoto no Yoshitsune, and Himiko.

You can check out Nioh 3 right now on PC and PlayStation 5. There's been no mention of ports to other systems yet, but given that Nioh has historically been exclusive to PlayStation (and PC), it's unlikely. Stay tuned for more.
